speaker: Véronique De Keyser (PSE).
english:
Véronique De Keyser (PSE). – (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, there was nothing random about the events in Jericho, which have deprived us of a meeting with Mahmoud Abbas; they are politically significant. The first person to be affected was certainly Mahmoud Abbas; hardly had he left his country than the Israeli forces launched their assault on the prison.
He is not the only one to be affected, though. It has not been mentioned that Ahmed Sa’adat was a member of the newly-elected Palestinian legislative council. Nor has anyone pointed out that Hamas, which had made tentative steps towards recognising the State of Israel within its 1967 borders, could not proceed any further towards such recognition, after the humiliating images of half-naked, bound and blindfolded prisoners.
We Europeans have also been snubbed. We were expecting Mahmoud Abbas but he did not come. What is at stake is our entire policy towards Palestine. Today, with our offices ransacked and our nationals taken hostage, there are some Members of this Chamber saying to me that we, the main donors, must not continue to finance Palestine, after the ingratitude shown. That has been the effect of Jericho.
I should like to say to those MEPs hesitating about supporting Palestine that there is not one Palestinian today who would not swap the money we are giving to Palestine for a firm EU stance on current events. Can we, after all, turn a blind eye to the fact that Israel has chosen a unilateral path, focused on law and order, which no longer has anything to do with the roadmap? The Olmert plan is a unilateral one, as were the Gaza disengagement - warmly applauded as it was - the annexing of the West Bank and the capture of East Jerusalem. The reality of Palestine is an interminable occupation and a wall which was condemned by the Hague but which is still standing. All the money that we give to Palestine to help it survive does not enable it to escape this reality. In other words, the peace process is dragging its feet.
To conclude, Commissioner, if there is to be a Plan B to help Palestine, Europe must take a clear and courageous stance. How otherwise can the Palestinians be expected to have hope and to believe us when we talk about the road map?
original:
Véronique De Keyser (PSE). - Monsieur le Président, Madame la Commissaire, les événements de Jéricho, qui nous ont privés de la rencontre avec Mahmoud Abbas, ne sont pas un simple fait divers. Ils ont une signification politique. Le premier visé est certainement Mahmoud Abbas, car à peine avait-il quitté son pays que l’assaut contre la prison était lancé par les forces israéliennes.
Mais il n’est pas le seul. On n’a pas dit qu’Ahmed Saadate était un membre du Conseil législatif palestinien nouvellement élu. On n’a pas dit et on n’a pas souligné que le Hamas, qui avait fait quelques pas timides vers la reconnaissance de l’État d’Israël en ses frontières de 1967, ne pouvait pas, après les images humiliantes de ces prisonniers à moitié nus, attachés, les yeux bandés, avancer encore dans la reconnaissance d’Israël.
Le camouflet a aussi été pour nous, Européens. Nous attendions Mahmoud Abbas: il n’est pas venu. C’est toute notre politique vis-à-vis de la Palestine qui est en jeu. Et aujourd’hui, face à nos bureaux saccagés et au kidnapping de nos ressortissants, des députés dans cette enceinte me disent: on ne va pas, nous, les principaux donateurs, continuer à financer la Palestine! Quels ingrats! C’est cela l’effet de Jéricho.
Je voudrais dire aux collègues qui hésitent à soutenir la Palestine qu’il n’y a pas un Palestinien aujourd’hui qui ne troquerait l’argent que nous donnons à la Palestine contre une position politique claire de l’Union européenne sur les événements actuels. Car pouvons-nous taire aujourd’hui qu’Israël a choisi une voie unilatérale et sécuritaire, qui n’a plus rien à voir avec la feuille de route. Le plan Olmert est unilatéral, comme l’était le désengagement - applaudi d’ailleurs - de Gaza, comme l’est l’annexion de la rive du Jourdain et la mainmise sur Jérusalem-Est. Telle est la réalité de la Palestine: une interminable occupation, un mur condamné par La Haye, mais qui est toujours debout. Et tout l’argent que nous donnons à la Palestine pour l’aider à survivre ne lui permet pas d’échapper à cette réalité. En d’autres termes, la paix marche aujourd’hui à reculons.
En conclusion, Madame la Commissaire, s’il faut un plan B pour aider la Palestine, il faut aussi et surtout que l’Europe prenne une position politique courageuse et claire. Comment voulez-vous, sinon, que les Palestiniens aient encore de l’espoir et qu’ils nous croient, quand nous parlons de la feuille de route?
agenda_item: Euro-Mediterranean policy/preparation for the next meeting of the Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly (debate)
summary_english:
{
  "headline": "EU Must Take Firm Stance on Palestine-Israel Conflict Beyond Financial Aid to Restore Peace Process",
  "issueSum": "The speaker addresses the failure of Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas to attend the Euro-Mediterranean meeting due to Israeli military action in Jericho, the impact on the Palestinian peace process, and the effectiveness of EU policy toward Palestine. Key issues include Israeli unilateral actions, the breakdown of the roadmap process, Palestinian prisoner treatment, and the adequacy of EU financial support versus political action.",
  "positionSum": "The speaker strongly criticizes Israel's unilateral approach and calls for a more assertive EU political stance toward the Palestine-Israel conflict. She argues that financial aid alone is insufficient and that Europe must take a clear, courageous political position to restore credibility in the peace process. She defends continued support for Palestine against those who want to withdraw aid.",
  "argSum": "Her arguments center on the political significance of the Jericho events undermining peace prospects, the humiliating treatment of Palestinian prisoners damaging Hamas's potential recognition of Israel, Israel's departure from the roadmap through unilateral actions, and the inadequacy of financial aid without accompanying firm political positions. She contends that Palestinians would prefer strong EU political stances over monetary assistance.",
  "propSum": "She calls for a 'Plan B' that involves Europe taking a clear and courageous political stance on the conflict, moving beyond just providing financial aid to Palestine. She advocates for continued EU support to Palestine while demanding stronger political action to address Israeli unilateral measures and restore hope in the peace process.",
  "quotes": [
    "there is not one Palestinian today who would not swap the money we are giving to Palestine for a firm EU stance on current events",
    "Can we, after all, turn a blind eye to the fact that Israel has chosen a unilateral path, focused on law and order, which no longer has anything to do with the roadmap",
    "if there is to be a Plan B to help Palestine, Europe must take a clear and courageous stance. How otherwise can the Palestinians be expected to have hope and to believe us when we talk about the road map"
  ]
}
summary_original:
```json
{
  "headline": "EU Must Take Clear Political Stance on Palestine-Israel Conflict Beyond Financial Aid",
  "issueSum": "The speaker addresses the Jericho events that prevented a meeting with Mahmoud Abbas, highlighting how Israeli actions have undermined Palestinian leadership and peace prospects. She criticizes Israel's unilateral security approach, including the construction of a wall condemned by The Hague, annexation activities, and the ongoing occupation. The speaker also addresses European offices being vandalized and EU nationals being kidnapped, which has led some MEPs to question continued Palestinian funding.",
  "positionSum": "The speaker strongly supports continued European engagement with Palestine and opposes cutting funding despite recent incidents. She argues that the EU must move beyond financial assistance to take a clear, courageous political position on the conflict. She criticizes Israel's unilateral approach and defends Palestinian frustrations, arguing that no Palestinian would trade EU financial aid for a clear European political stance on current events.",
  "argSum": "Her arguments center on the political significance of recent events, particularly how Israeli actions deliberately undermine Palestinian leadership and peace processes. She contends that Israel's unilateral security approach contradicts the roadmap for peace, and that European financial aid alone cannot address the fundamental reality of occupation. She argues that without a clear EU political position, Palestinians will lose hope and faith in European peace efforts.",
  "propSum": "She calls for the EU to develop a 'Plan B' for helping Palestine that goes beyond financial assistance. Most importantly, she advocates for Europe to take a 'courageous and clear political position' on the conflict, moving beyond just providing financial aid to actually addressing the political realities of the occupation.",
  "quotes": [
    "il n'y a pas un Palestinien aujourd'hui qui ne troquerait l'argent que nous donnons à la Palestine contre une position politique claire de l'Union européenne sur les événements actuels",
    "Israël a choisi une voie unilatérale et sécuritaire, qui n'a plus rien à voir avec la feuille de route",
    "s'il faut un plan B pour aider la Palestine, il faut aussi et surtout que l'Europe prenne une position politique courageuse et claire"
  ]
}
```
